admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project provides for
            reconstruction of roads and drainage works damaged by
            cyclone "Wally" which hit Viti Levu, Fiji's
            largest island, in April 1980. Works will include
            reconstruction and realignment of a 32 km section of the
            Suva-Nadi highway; restoration of seawalls, outfall
            structures, and drains for about 12,000 ha; and dredging of
            rivers to remove flood-deposited sediments and thereby
            restore their flood discharge capacity. The proposed
            reconstruction of the 32 km long section of the Suva-Nadi
            highway would eliminate the problems of an unstable
            alignment subject to landslide and thereby reduce
            disruptions to traffic and avoid the need for costly repairs
            and maintenance. The benefits due to the restoration and
            expansion of the drainage works would be in bringing
            cyclone-damaged land back into production and providing
            conditions for further expansion of cultivation. There are
            no institutional risks since PWD and DID have considerable
            experience in works similar to those included in the
            project. The cost of the highway component may exceed
            estimates if unusually severe storms damage work in progress
            but this would not jeopardize the successful completion of
            the project.
